content: The Act may be cited as the "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999" and includes definitions. The "Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999" defines various welfare programs including TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, WIC, and child support enforcement. The Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999 defines welfare programs such as TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, WIC, child support enforcement, child welfare, and child care. The Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999 defines welfare programs like TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, WIC, child support enforcement, child welfare, and child care. The term "Y2K compliant" refers to information technology accurately processing date and time data between the 20th and 21st centuries, including leap year calculations. Grants are provided to states to ensure state and local government programs are Y2K compliant. The Secretary of Commerce awards grants to states for Y2K compliance in state and local government programs. Priority is given to requests related to Federal welfare programs. Limitations include a maximum of 75 grants and only 2 grants per state. Application deadline is 45 days after enactment. The Secretary of Commerce awards grants for Y2K compliance in state and local government programs. Each state can receive up to 2 grants, with an application deadline of 45 days after enactment. The application must include a proposed plan and budget for the compliance program. The application for Y2K compliance grants must include a proposed plan, budget, and funding source. States awarded a grant must match $1 for every $2 awarded. The grant application must include a proposed plan, budget, and funding source. States awarded a grant must match $1 for every $2 awarded, with a waiver available for hardship cases. The Secretary of Commerce may waive or modify the matching requirement for States facing undue hardship. State expenditures required for grants can be in cash, equipment, or services, with no credit for pre-award expenditures. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications based on feasibility and achieving program goals. Grants under this section cannot exceed a 2-year period. Funds provided to States under a grant are subject to specific requirements. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications for feasibility and goal achievement. Grants under this section are limited to a 2-year period. State funds awarded under a grant remain available without fiscal year limitation.
